week2_picks_results.upset_watch: MHJTIME +1.5 over Gen Ken-obi: LOST (Ken-obi won 124.72-113.92)

essay:
Hunter Henry scored twenty-five points. Let that marinate. For two solid weeks — and one very pointed preseason essay — this column had one recurring message for the Legion of Bouz: Mahomes and ARSB deserve a tight end with a pulse. The group chat agreed. The models agreed. The roster screamed it. And then Week 3 happened, and Hunter Henry — the tight end who was supposedly the roster’s fatal flaw — went off for 25.0, anchoring a 191.34-point explosion that crowned the Legion as the league’s new number one.

{{media:week3-essay-opener}}

The irony would be delicious if it weren’t so humbling. But Hunter Henry’s resurrection wasn’t even the most absurd stat of the week. That honor belongs to the Minnesota Vikings defense, which dropped 35.0 points for the Boonist Monks — the single highest individual performance in the entire league — and the Monks still lost. Lamar Jackson added 27.02, James Cook rolled for 19.3, and the final tally read 166.82 points... for a loss. Because the Legion had 191.34. The preseason dead-last-to-number-one fairy tale just hit its first plot twist, and the group chat is scrambling to update its power-rankings discourse for the third consecutive week.

Last week’s “Things I Believe But Can’t Prove” predicted that Father Time would win four straight starting in Week 3. Father Time scored 105.22 — the lowest total in the league — and lost to the Sleeping Giants by 38.42 points. The four-game win streak lasted approximately negative one games. We stand by nothing.

{{media:week3-prediction-bust}}

Kittler on the Roof reminded everyone that defending champions don’t need drama — just Jonathan Taylor’s 31.3-point masterclass and a 40.2-point demolition of Rasheeing the Scene that felt like the final act of a John Wick film: methodical, overwhelming, no survivors. Three teams sit unbeaten at 3-0 — the Legion, Kittler, and General Ken-obi — and two of them weren’t even in the preseason top five. The pecking order is crystallizing, and it looks nothing like what we predicted in August.

MHJTIME, the league’s points leader through two weeks, crashed back to earth with 113.92 — a 68.88-point nosedive from last week’s 182.8. The historic WR trio? None of them cracked the top five scorers. Instead, Quinshon Judkins (16.0) and Daniel Jones (15.82) led the way. When your backup quarterback is your second-highest scorer, the group chat doesn’t need to roast you. The stat line does it for free.

The bottom of the standings is hardening. Three teams sit at 0-3 — Father Time, Chudders, and Burden of Etienne-y Woody — and the paths diverge sharply. Chudders is playing for 2026 with a war chest of picks; the losing was always part of the plan. Burden has Justin Jefferson and still can’t crack 134 points. The franchise player hasn’t led his own team’s scoring all season, and the trade whispers are becoming trade plans.

On the upside, the Sleeping Giants quietly bounced back from last week’s six-spot tumble with a 143.64-point performance. Jalen Hurts’ 29.04 was a full redemption tour after his 10.54 disaster in Week 2. The Giants are now 8-0 all-time against Father Time — a head-to-head record so lopsided it deserves its own entry in the Jailyard Bible.

Three weeks in. Three undefeated. Three winless. Six teams in the messy middle. And the question that will define the next month: which of these narratives are real, and which ones are just noise?

rankings.blurb: We wrote it in the preseason. We repeated it in Week 1. We said it again in Week 2: “Mahomes and ARSB deserve a tight end with a pulse.” Hunter Henry heard us. The man dropped 25.0 points — the highest tight end performance of the season — and your 191.34-point week was the kind of offensive detonation that makes other managers close their fantasy apps and stare at the ceiling. Cam Skattebo added 21.1 from the running back spot, Christian McCaffrey contributed 19.0, and T.J. Watt chipped in 18.5 from IDP. You beat the number-one ranked Boonist Monks by 24.52, and you did it without Amon-Ra St. Brown even cracking your top five. Since winning the inaugural title in 2022, you’ve been stuck in the middle — that was the narrative anyway. At 3-0 with the highest single-week score of the season, the middle is in your rearview mirror. Your Elo jumped 20.8 points this week. The Voltron receivers finally have reinforcements at every position, and the rest of the league is officially on notice.

Jonathan Taylor put up 31.3 points and didn’t even bother being subtle about it. The defending champion delivered the biggest blowout of Week 3 — a 40.2-point evisceration of Rasheeing the Scene that felt like a championship reminder wrapped in a statement game. Derwin James contributed 23.0 from the defensive backfield, Garrett Wilson added 19.4, and the Kansas City Chiefs defense pitched in 18.0 for good measure. Runner-up in 2022, runner-up in 2023, champion in 2024, and now 3-0 in 2025 — your consistency isn’t just a trend, it’s a personality trait. We said your ceiling was drywall. Drywall just dropped 184.42 points. The preseason listed zero roster needs for you, and three weeks in, the models look prophetic: no holes, no drama, just wins. The group chat keeps making Tony Pollard three-yard-carry jokes, and you keep cashing checks. At some point the rest of the league needs to stop underestimating the quietest contender in the building.

Three-and-oh looks good on the franchise everyone measures themselves against. Drake Maye’s 20.22 wasn’t the kind of performance that dominates the group chat, but paired with Nico Collins’ 18.4, Kenneth Walker’s 17.5, and the Tampa Bay defense’s 19.0, it was more than enough to handle MHJTIME’s 113.92. You’re winning with depth rather than explosions — your 124.72 was actually the lowest score among the three undefeated teams — and yet the 3-0 record speaks louder than the weekly totals. Your Elo hit 1700.2 this week, a new all-time franchise peak. We spent the preseason calling your roster the All-Pro team, and through three weeks you’re proving us right in the most boring, effective way possible. The taxi squad debates have been shelved. The CeeDee Lamb questions from Week 1 feel like ancient history. You’re doing what preseason favorites are supposed to do: winning games that don’t require heroics and saving the heroics for when you need them.

Gravity arrived, and it brought receipts of its own. Your Minnesota Vikings defense scored 35.0 points — the single highest individual performance in the league this week — and you still lost by 24.52. Lamar Jackson added 27.02. James Cook contributed 19.3. Jaxon Smith-Njigba posted 18.1. You scored 166.82 total points — enough to beat nine of the eleven other teams in the league this week. Unfortunately, you drew the one that dropped 191.34. That’s the cruelest version of the scheduling coin flip, and it came for the franchise that was sitting at number one with a bullet and two weeks of group-chat receipts. We said the schedule gets real in Week 3 — it got real. You’re 2-1 with the highest total points in the league at 479.9, which means the production is there even if the record doesn’t match. Sound familiar? MHJTIME lived this exact narrative last week. Your Elo dropped 20.8 points, and the preseason dead-last-to-number-one story isn’t over — it’s just developing a subplot.

Fifth in the preseason. Second in Week 1 after Josh Allen’s 38.76 made everyone briefly reconsider. Then fifth again in Week 2. And fifth again in Week 3. No matter how high you spike, the gravitational pull back to fifth is inescapable — and honestly, there are worse orbits to be stuck in. Josh Allen’s 22.02 was solid, Courtland Sutton popped for 20.8, and De’Von Achane added 12.6 — but none of it mattered against Kittler’s 184.42-point buzzsaw. The 40.2-point loss was the biggest margin of defeat this week, and it’s worth noting that your preseason essay warned about this exact profile: weekly thrill rides that occasionally crash into a guardrail. Two-and-one with 423.6 total points is respectable, but your Elo took a 17.1-point hit, and Michael Pittman (16.3) being your fourth-highest scorer speaks to the WR depth problem we’ve been flagging since August. The chat consensus was to invest in a steady WR1 rather than another speedster. After a 40-point loss, that advice is starting to feel prophetic.

The Island of Misfit WR1s is back from the dead — again. After tumbling from first to seventh last week on the strength of a Brandon Aubrey-led scoring column, you answered with a dominant 143.64-point performance and a 38.42-point thrashing of Father Time. Jalen Hurts’ 29.04 was a full redemption tour after last week’s 10.54 debacle, Kyren Williams added 18.2, and even the aging Keenan Allen kicked in 16.0. You’re now 8-0 all-time against Father Time — a perfect head-to-head record that the group chat will absolutely turn into a meme if it hasn’t already. The preseason ranked you eleventh and said your veterans were on borrowed time. At 2-1, the loan has been extended. You rode Hurts and a deep backfield to the 2024 final, and three weeks into 2025, the formula looks familiar: let Hurts cook, grind with the running backs, and hope the receivers hold together long enough to make noise. The window might be closing, but it’s not closed yet.

From 182.8 to 113.92 in the span of seven days. That’s not a correction — that’s a 68.88-point freefall that landed with a thud heard across the group chat. Your top scorer was Quinshon Judkins at 16.0. Your second-highest scorer was Daniel Jones at 15.82. The historic WR trio — Chase, Nabers, Marvin Harrison Jr. — was completely invisible, and none of them cracked your top five. Last week you were the league’s most dangerous 1-1 team with the highest point total in the Jailyard. This week you lost to General Ken-obi by 10.8 and dropped below .500 for the first time since the toilet bowl days of 2023. Trey McBride managed 12.8 and the rest of the roster essentially took a nap. The preseason said you were “a trade or rookie breakout away from a title.” Right now you’re a consistent WR performance away from relevance. You’re 3-5 all-time against Ken-obi, and at 1-2, the “what if” label from the preseason is starting to sound less like a warning and more like a prophecy.

The preseason number two finally remembered how to win, and it only took Caleb Williams going nuclear with 29.12 to get there. A.J. Brown added 19.9, Ricky Pearsall chipped in 15.7, and Bijan Robinson — the RB god — contributed 13.6 in a steady-as-she-goes performance that feels undersized for a player of his caliber. The 136.22-point victory over Chudders by 17.32 wasn’t dominant, but after an 0-2 start that had the group chat questioning whether “the scariest backfield in the league” was actually scary, any W feels medicinal. You’re 1-2 with 398.5 total points — still below the league average — and the supporting cast issue we flagged in the preseason hasn’t gone away. Isaiah Likely didn’t crack the top five. Breece Hall didn’t crack the top five. When your kicker Will Reichard (15.7) ties your WR2 for third-highest scorer, the tight end need is real and the depth concern is louder. But Williams showed what a full-throttle QB1 performance can do for this roster. More of that, please.

One win and a 24.4-point Elo spike later, the blueprint is showing signs of life. Omarion Hampton’s 20.9 was the kind of explosive RB performance you’ve been waiting for since you cashed in picks for young runners, and J.K. Dobbins added 14.8 from the same position group. The Pittsburgh Steelers defense led your scoring with 22.0, Brian Burns contributed 18.5, and Nick Bolton added 16.0 — an IDP-heavy effort that masked the fact that your receiver room still isn’t producing a true alpha. The 30.5-point victory over Burden was emphatic and it snapped a losing streak that was heading toward uncomfortable territory. You’re 1-2 and ninth in the rankings, but your 164.06 this week was actually higher than both MHJTIME and General Ken-obi’s totals. We said your pick stash was bigger than your WR room — and it still is — but when Hampton and the IDP crew are hitting like this, the picks are starting to look like they converted into something tangible. The chat’s “picks don’t score points” refrain might need a new verse.

Last week, this column’s “Things I Believe But Can’t Prove” section predicted you would win four straight starting in Week 3. You responded with 105.22 points — the lowest total in the league — and a 38.42-point loss to the Sleeping Giants, who are now 8-0 against you all-time. That’s not a rivalry; that’s a restraining order with a scoreboard. Davante Adams led your squad with 14.1, Rome Odunze added 13.7, and Bo Nix posted 13.42 — three perfectly mediocre performances that add up to a perfectly mediocre week. The wagyu beef WRs are currently producing at ramen-noodle levels, and the RB room we flagged as your weakest position group delivered Jaylen Warren’s 10.6 as its best effort. You’ve scored 391.0 total points through three weeks, which is actually middle of the pack, but you’re 0-3 because the schedule keeps serving you opponents having their best week. The preseason said the chat would love your random 180-point weeks and ignore the rest. Three weeks in, there hasn’t been a random 180-point week to love.

Jahmyr Gibbs put up 24.4 points and reminded everyone that the rebuild has a heartbeat — it’s just surrounded by organs that aren’t fully developed yet. Justin Herbert added 15.6, Jared Verse contributed 15.0 from the IDP slot, and Emeka Egbuka managed 11.5 — a quieter encore to his 21.6 debut in Week 1 and his 10.9 follow-up in Week 2. The loss to Noble FFT by 17.32 wasn’t surprising; rebuilding teams don’t beat preseason top-two rosters when they’re clicking. Your 118.9 total points and 365.5 season total both rank eleventh. We said you were playing for 2026, and nothing about 0-3 changes that timeline. The war chest of picks remains untouched, and the chat is still joking about you icing trade offers. Keep icing. But watch the waiver wire too — Egbuka’s inconsistency (21.6, 10.9, 11.5) suggests the WR1 of the future might need some company. You’re bench-pressing next to the trophy case, and the weights are getting heavier.

Rock bottom is a location, and you’ve been parked here for three weeks. Jordan Mason led your scorers with 23.6 — a strong performance from a running back who wasn’t even in your preseason spotlight — and George Pickens added 16.3, Dalton Kincaid contributed 15.1, and Kyler Murray posted 14.06. The problem isn’t any single player; it’s that 133.56 total points in a loss to a 1-2 Ghastly Grayskull team is the kind of result that makes the Jefferson trade rumors less a rumor and more a business imperative. You’re 0-3 with a league-worst 352.7 total points and a point differential that screams structural overhaul. Justin Jefferson — the top-three dynasty asset we said could only carry you so far — hasn’t led his own team’s scoring in any week this season. Your Elo dropped 24.4 points to 1323.5, near the league floor. We warned about quarterback roulette and running-back triage in the preseason. The roulette wheel keeps landing on zero. At some point the rebuild stops being optional and starts being obvious.

confessionals.text: My defense scored thirty-five points. Thirty-five. The Vikings defense put up more than most starting quarterbacks in this league. Lamar had twenty-seven. Cook had nineteen. I scored a hundred and sixty-six and lost. Lost. The group chat was roasting me before the final scores were even official. Two weeks of receipts, two weeks of ‘dead last to number one,’ and the Legion of Bouz just hit me with a hundred and ninety-one like it was nothing. I need a moment.

Last week I scored 182.8. This week, 113.92. My top scorer was Quinshon Judkins. My second-highest scorer was Daniel Jones. I have Ja’Marr Chase, Malik Nabers, and Marvin Harrison Jr. on my roster and none of them showed up. The column called my WR trio ‘historic.’ Historic at what — taking weeks off? I’m 1-2 with the talent to be 3-0 and I can’t explain this to anyone, least of all myself.

The column — this column, the one you’re reading right now — predicted I would win four straight starting this week. I scored 105 points. I lost by thirty-eight. I’m 0-3. The Sleeping Giants are 8-0 against me all-time. All. Time. I’d like to file a formal complaint against the concept of optimism.

For weeks, the entire column has been writing one thing about my team: ‘Mahomes and ARSB deserve a tight end with a pulse.’ Hunter Henry just scored twenty-five points. Twenty-five. From the position everyone said was my fatal flaw. I’m not going to say I told you so. But I’m also not NOT going to say it. The tight end has a pulse, and it’s beating loudly.

mailbag.question: Dear Commish: The ‘Things I Believe But Can’t Prove’ section predicted Father Time would win four straight. Father Time scored 105 and lost by 38. Should we retire the segment?
mailbag.answer: The segment stands by its process. The segment also concedes that 105.22 points and an 0-3 record represent a significant deviation from the model. The segment will be taking next week off to ‘recalibrate.’ The segment is sorry.

mailbag.question: From the group chat: The Boonist Monks’ defense scored 35 points and they still lost. How is that mathematically possible?
mailbag.answer: It’s possible when the Legion of Bouz decides to put up 191.34 on your head. The Vikings defense outscored every starting quarterback in the league this week. It just happened to play for the team matched against the one squad that went nuclear.

mailbag.question: @zbcowan asks: Is my 8-0 all-time record against Father Time the most dominant rivalry in Jailyard history?
mailbag.answer: It might be. It’s also less a rivalry and more like a subscription service — Father Time signs up to lose every time and never cancels. The data speaks, and what it’s saying is deeply unkind.

mailbag.question: Dear Commish: MHJTIME went from 182.8 to 113.92 in one week. Is that a record for biggest week-over-week drop?
mailbag.answer: Unclear, but a 68.88-point swing deserves its own chapter in the Jailyard Bible. None of the historic WR trio even cracked MHJTIME’s top five scorers — Quinshon Judkins and Daniel Jones led the way instead. The schedule gods giveth and the schedule gods taketh away, and they apparently have a sense of humor.

mailbag.question: From the group chat: The picks column went 3-3 this week after going 5-1 in Week 1. Is regression real?
mailbag.answer: Regression is real, painful, and arrived right on schedule. The 8-4 cumulative record is still profitable, but picking MHJTIME over General Ken-obi and Father Time over the Sleeping Giants were the kind of heart picks that feel smart until the scoreboard disagrees.

bits.title: IDP Monster of the Week
bits.text: The Minnesota Vikings defense scoring 35.0 points for the Boonist Monks is the single highest individual performance of Week 3 — and maybe the most wasted one. When your IDP monster outscores every quarterback in the league and you still lose by 24.52, the monster isn’t the problem. Everything around it is.

bits.title: Preseason Prediction Tracker
bits.text: Picks column record: Week 1 went 5-1, Week 2 went 3-3, cumulative 8-4. The Lock of the Week (Kittler -2.5 over Rasheeing) cashed comfortably with a 40.2-point blowout. The Upset Watch (MHJTIME +1.5 over Gen Ken-obi) missed — Ken-obi won by 10.8. Father Time’s predicted four-game win streak lasted negative one games.

bits.title: Nobody Believes In Us Award
bits.text: The Sleeping Giants, who went from first to seventh to back up to sixth with a 38.42-point beatdown of Father Time. Jalen Hurts’ 29.04 after last week’s 10.54 is the kind of swing that makes you remember why you drafted the man. The Island of Misfit WR1s might be misfit, but they’re not done.

bits.title: Is Hunter Henry the New Kelce?
bits.text: Hear me out: a tight end on an aging roster anchored by a legendary quarterback, dismissed by pundits all offseason, suddenly becomes the missing piece that elevates the whole team. Henry’s 25.0 isn’t Kelce’s prime, but for a position group that was described as ‘empty,’ it’s a revelation. If Henry sustains even 60% of this production, the Legion of Bouz goes from interesting to terrifying.

bits.title: Overheard in the Chat
bits.text: ‘My defense scored thirty-five and I lost’ — @GauchoTrain, who may need to be checked on. ‘We’re 8-0 against Father Time. That’s not a rivalry, that’s a subscription service’ — @zbcowan, who is not wrong.

picks.blurb: The Monks are licking wounds from a 24.52-point loss to the Legion, but Lamar Jackson and James Cook don’t stay down for long. Chudders’ 118.9 last week was propped up by Gibbs’ 24.4 — take that away and the supporting cast isn’t scary. The Monks win, but don’t expect another 69.9-point blowout. Those days are behind us. Probably.

Jonathan Taylor just put up 31.3 and the defending champ is rolling. Ghastly’s 164.06 last week showed promise, but that total was heavily IDP-dependent and hard to replicate. Kittler grinds it out, extends to 4-0, and the group chat starts whispering about a repeat. Which might be warranted.

Burden’s 0-3 start and 352.7 total points don’t inspire confidence. The Giants just demolished Father Time by 38.42 and Jalen Hurts is back in form after his Week 2 hiccup. Unless Justin Jefferson decides to remind everyone why he’s a top-three asset, this feels one-sided. Giants handle business.

Two teams desperate for different things: Noble needs momentum after finally breaking the 0-2 curse, Father Time needs literally any win. Caleb Williams’ 29.12 was a breakthrough, and Bijan Robinson’s floor is matchup-proof. Father Time’s 105.22 last week was uninspiring. Noble’s talent advantage should close this one out.

The number-one team versus a squad that just put up 113.92? Normally this is a layup for the Legion. But MHJTIME’s floor last week was a historic anomaly — this roster has 439.3 total points despite a 1-2 record. Chase, Nabers, and Harrison Jr. will bounce back because superstars always do. If the 182.8 version shows up instead of the 113.92 version, this is a genuine upset. Taking the gamble.

The preseason number one is 3-0 and sitting at its all-time Elo peak. Rasheeing just got blasted by 40.2 against Kittler and Josh Allen can’t do it alone — especially against a roster this deep. Ken-obi’s 124.72 wasn’t explosive, but the defense, the depth, and the balance make them the right side of this matchup. The franchise everyone measures themselves against keeps measuring up.

special_picks.stay_away: Noble FFT vs Father Time (both squads too inconsistent to trust)
special_picks.teaser: Kittler -1.0 / Boonist Monks -2.5 — two proven commodities teased down to near-gimme territory

media_slots.intent: The moment the tight end everyone dismissed proves the doubters wrong
media_slots.alt_text: Smug reaction after proving the doubters wrong about the tight end position

media_slots.intent: A bold prediction going hilariously wrong immediately
media_slots.alt_text: Reaction to a bold prediction completely busting in Week 3
